properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. An approaching frontal system will track inland today and stall across the southern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening and persist through Friday. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm can be expected by late Friday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T03:48:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T11:49:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4048405595.2019
Area: Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An approaching Pacific frontal system will track inland later today and stall across the southern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening and then change to showers Friday morning, with local amounts of at least 10 cm expected in West Kelowna, Peachland, Sicamous and Grand Forks. General snowfall accumulations of near 5 cm are forecast elsewhere. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T03:47:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T11:48:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1965541673.2019
Area: Central Okanagan - including Kelowna, Shuswap, Boundary
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Beginning tonight, a stream of pacific moisture will bring a sharp contrast in weather across the Rocky Mountains until Saturday morning. Communities and highways close to the British Columbia border could see total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 centimetres, while the eastern slopes of the Rockies will see warm, dry, and gusty conditions. Warming temperatures could cause some precipitation to fall as rain or wet snow, especially in valleys at lower elevations. Holiday travel through the mountains could be difficult Friday and Saturday on routes such as highways 1, 3 and 93. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T09:55:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T17:56:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3473718551.2019

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts near 15 cm is expected tonight. An approaching Pacific frontal system will track inland today and stall across the southern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening with 15 cm expected before changing to rain Friday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. The coldest wind chill values will be between minus 55 and minus 60. Extreme cold conditions are expected to persist until Friday for most of the Kitikmeot. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T07:28:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T15:29:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0901620100.2019
Area: Kugluktuk, Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Snowfall is expected to begin this evening, bringing 15 to 25 centimetres of snow to Highway 93 north of Lake Louise by Friday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T09:29:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T17:30:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3224597575.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The coldest wind chill values will be near minus 50. A strong arctic ridge of high pressure across northern Yukon will give temperatures near minus 40 today through the weekend. A gentle breeze at times will result in wind chill values reaching minus 50. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T05:17:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T13:18:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3681211319.2019
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong wind gusts are expected to continue until this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T23:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T15:41:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3750095927.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. An approaching Pacific frontal system will track inland late today and stall across the southern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening with 10 to 15 cm expected before changing to showers Friday morning. There is also the risk of freezing rain late overnight and early Friday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An approaching frontal system will track inland today and stall across the southern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy will begin this evening and persist through Friday. Snowfall amounts of 30 to 60 cm can be expected by late Friday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific frontal system will move into the southern interior tonight and then remain stalled over the region through Friday. Snow will redevelop this evening and become heavy at times tonight and Friday resulting in snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm. The snow will likely become mixed with rain in the valley bottoms Friday afternoon as temperatures rise above freezing. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T03:41:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T11:42:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1855757852.2019

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A Pacific frontal system approaching the south coast will spread rain heavy at times to the Fraser Valley late this afternoon. The rain will persist tonight and Friday giving total amounts of 50 to 70 mm. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-20T04:43:49-00:00
